abstracts.cdata!:
The Sustainable Forestry Investment
            Project for Nicaragua had the following ratings: the outcome
            was unsatisfactory, the sustainability was likely, the
            institutional development impact was substantial, and the
            Bank and borrower performance were both satisfactory. The
            lessons learned indicate that in order to understand
            specific lessons from the execution of the subprojects, and
            to address the long term forestry issues in Nicaragua, the
            PCU commissioned two studies. Innovative projects should not
            necessarily reflect the prevailing Bank's strategy for
            the sector. Deforestation, inter alia, is the result of
            assigning low value to forest and forest products. Success
            in establishing sustainable forestry sector management
            requires effective and meaningful participation of
            stakeholders. Political support and Government commitment to
            a long-term goal will create confidence in the system.
            Sustainable forestry development efforts cannot succeed
            without a holistic approach that deals with land security
            and agricultural productivity. New technology transfers that
            are appropriate and divisible are not necessarily expensive.
            Assigning forests protective status might be less efficient
            unless supported by an incentive mechanism to support
            sustainable management.

repnme.cdata!:
Nicaragua - Sustainable Forestry Investment
            Promotion Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Sustainable Forestry Investment
            Promotion Project seeks to improve local capacity and
            develop alternatives to address long term forestry issues in
            Nicaragua. The project consists of four components. 1)
            Technical assistance to private and communal sector forestry
            will finance technical assistance, training, workshops,
            studies, office equipment and supplies, vehicles, and
            operational expenses. 2) Assistance to forestry sector
            institutional reform will finance technical assistance and
            training to the Ministry of Agriculture and Livestock. 3)
            Pilot subprojects will develop and test innovative
            activities and new mechanisms for finding solutions to
            priority forestry sector problems, including innovative
            models for reforestation and land rehabilitation, forestry
            resource management, increasing decentralization of forestry
            functions, public-private sector partnerships, creative
            financing mechanisms for sustainable forestry management and
            reforestation. The project will finance a program of grants
            to private sector, nongovernmental organizations,
            communities, and municipalities to carry out the pilot
            sub-projects which included specific actions for monitoring
            and evaluating the results of implementation. 4) The last
            component will finance the Project Coordination Unit, which
            is responsible for overall project administration.
